The government certainly did not have to sponsor the railroads. In fact, the only railroad to escape bankruptcy in the 1890s was Great Northern. They bought their rights of way as they could afford to and made each one profitable before moving to the next section. The UP, SP, and others used land speculation that backfired spectacularly on them. No, the government was not necessary for the railroads. In fact, it hindered profitability as it still does today.

Most states do not have balanced budget amendments.

There was no citizenship offer under the Dawes Act. That didn't come until 1926 under the American Indian Citizenship Act.

The Chief Joseph quote is from when the federal government forced the Niimipuu (Nez Perce) people to give up 90% of their lands guaranteed in the 1855 Stevens Treaty in the 1863 Nez Perce Treaty. He and others refused to accept or recognize it. It would eventually lead to the 1877 "Nez Perce War."

Pennsylvania was far from the only place Indian children were sent to boarding school. It was simply the first and most (in)famous.

The Oregon Trail was not separated from anything by the American Civil War. Use began with the fur trappers in the 1820s. It was used continuously until nearly 1900. You can still see the ruts of wagons left in the earth in several parts of the trail today. If you do, you'll never complain about Michigan highways ever again.

That same thing happened in the U.S., so much so that there were entire villages literally without any children left. Congress passed the Indian Child Welfare Act in 1978, but honestly, it's still happening. States get paid by the government for each child taken into foster care, often more if they're Native American. Some are taken out of bad situations of course, but others are basically just kidnapped by the state. It can be misleading to compare American history with that of other countries. For example, things are more complicated than saying Aboriginal history in Australia is comparable with American Indian history. This is not to diminish any of the issues, but simply not to equate them without qualification. The policy of removal of Aboriginal children from families was well after most settler expansion. What's notable is that it was substantially motivated by a misguided view of 'protecting' them, and it was a patronising elite that most promoted it. It's worthwhile reflecting that what we now regard as reprehensible was driven by what many perceived as the best of intentions. It was also accompanied by a similar and even larger 'white stolen generation' in Australia that was consistent with the equally reprehensible 'baby scooping' practices in many western countries. The question that often occurs to me is "What are we doing now, that we think is awesomely well intentioned and terribly well informed, that will be seen as utterly repulsive by future generations?"

Fun fact: America did live up to at least one myth. The urban legend goes: There are two women who decide to sit down at a restaurant counter and decide to just have two Cokes. It's a pretty dimly lit place since it seems pretty cheap and the restaurant must be saving money on lighting. So the women decide that they should order the Coke in bottles and pour their own glasses. One woman gets hers and takes a sip and says it tastes funny. The other says hers tastes just fine, so the first woman keeps drinking. But when she goes to pour her second glass, she realizes there's something coming out: a partially decomposed mouse corpse.
Between 1939 and 1974, there were 44, I think (Might have been 40), court cases about mice in soda bottles, so people actually DID find little bodies in bottles. ((I found out about this in Jan Harold Brunvand's "The Vanishing Hitchhiker"))

The American buffalo (scientific name: Bison bison if that's a hint) is not a buffalo, being as related to that genus as it is to antelope. More properly called the American bison, it is one of two extant species of its genus. The other is the European... (wait for it) ...bison (scientific name: Bison bonasus). Outside of zoos, buffalo have never roamed any homes on the range in the Americas and Buffalo, NY (and the eponymous wings) is named after a taxonomic mistake.

In a college history class, my professor asked why we thought the US didn't engage in imperialism in the 1800s like Europe did. After some discussion where no one challenged the question at all, I was just staring at the US map when a lightbulb went off in my head. And I said, "But we did. We took over an entire continent. The people who lived there were nations we conquered." The room was dead silent after that. We're just not taught to think of Indians like that, and it's insulting.

It's astonishing to me that I didn't learn about allotment until literally the last possible moment in my education-- my final semester in law school when I took the totally elective class of Federal Indian Law. It did always feel like there was a gap in my US History classes, where we just stopped talking about the Natives until the 1970s (if we got that far), but then no one had ever taught me that the tribes had been treated as sovereign nations up until a certain point either.

One of the reasons we have to deal with "white guilt" is that we are just the first generation to begin to recognize the truth of our past and are still in the process of changing the country's collective perception.  "Bury My Heart At Wounded Knee" was written in 1970, before which there was no history other then the glory of the white man.  Besides, our true history is still to this day, 43 years later, taught on the margins or not at all in the nations schools.

Another disadvantage the Indians had was simply their unsophisticated society. If the Indians sensed that they were losing, they would often break and run at times that US soldiers would attempt to rally and regain the advantage. This was because the Indians could not tolerate heavy casualties.  When every male is a warrior, where do you go for replacements when you've had 50% casualties in a big fight? Our soldiers could just requisition more from back east and keep up a relentless pursuit.

The Indians fought bravely and were master tacticians. Their biggest problem was that they did not think strategically. They never developed a long term plan to defeat the whites. They would just get angry and plan a tactical action against any whites they could find.  I think their best bet would be to unite all tribes, form an alliance with some European power, maybe the British, and hit strategic targets like railroads, then sue for peace when and if the US has had enough.

I don't think Western tactics gave us a significant advantage in the Indian Wars.  Once the started using metal arrowheads, the Indians had the advantage over muskets. They had a much higher rate of fire and muskets missed most of the time.  Rifles could be very accurate as far as 300 yards, but took even longer to load than muskets. When repeaters were invented, Indians began using them while the Army, being cheap, outfitted soldiers with breech loaders.

The military situation was dire and some British officers attempted to spread smallpox among the Indians using infected blankets.  It isn't known if it had any effect.
